Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Resolving centennial- to millennial-scale trends in glacier extent and lake sedimentation in the Brooks Range, Arctic Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this collaborative project to reconstruct late Quaternary climate and glacier change in Arctic Alaska, one of few regions in the Arctic where mountain glaciers have left physical records of their former extent, making it valuable for comparing the timing and extent of mountain glacier variability between the lower latitudes and the Arctic. Several features of the climate and glacier history of the Brooks Range contrast with those from the North Atlantic region (which is often taken to represent the entire Northern Hemisphere in records of climate change) and currently available evidence indicates that the history of the Brooks Range more closely resembles glacier records from the southern Hemisphere. The investigators propose to develop records of climate change from lake sediments and records of glacier fluctuations using proglacial lake sediments and beryllium-10 dating of glacial features to address questions centered around four intervals of pronounced global change: (1) Last Glacial Maximum: Did glaciers retreat and temperatures increase in Arctic Alaska during the global LGM, as has been simulated by climate models? (2) Deglaciation: To what extent did climate change in Arctic Alaska coincide with North Atlantic climate fluctuations during deglaciation? (3) Holocene Glaciation: What was the extent of glaciers during (a) the Holocene thermal maximum, and (b) Neoglaciation? (4) Little Ice Age: Was it wetter or drier in the Brooks Range? The research will take place in suitable valleys (floatplane accessible valley with extant glaciers) in the northÂ­central Brooks Range. The project has several educational components, including support four graduate students and several undergraduate students and visits to the community of Anaktuvuk Pass to deliver presentations on climate research and the Brooks Range. The proposed research aims to produce well-dated and quantitative records of glacier and climate variability in the northernmost glaciated region of the U.S. Documenting the past behavior of arctic glaciers when subject to extreme climate events during the late glacial period and warm intervals like the Holocene can provide valuable insight to help better predict responses to future change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the Earth warms to record levels, climate scientists are striving to understand regional manifestations of global warming. The Arctic is warming two to three times faster than the planet on average. In turn, dramatic changes in the Arctic, such as the loss of sea ice and retreat of glaciers, affect the entire planet through powerful feedbacks involving the reflectivity of the globe, the decay of organic carbon stored in permafrost and through sea-level rise. For this project, collaborative investigators from Northern Arizona University, the University at Buffalo, and Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory used a variety of evidence from geological archives to put this rapid Arctic climate change into a longer-term context. They used evidence from lake sediment and isotopic dating of glacier-geological features to determine the history of glacier fluctuations and other climatic changes during the last deglacial cycle and during the current interglacial period at several sites in the north-central Brooks Range in Arctic Alaska.

Among the significant discoveries are those related to the precise timing of climate-driven changes as inferred from lake sediments and glacial geological features. One discovery relates to the local timing of warming that occurred in the Brooks Range as the Earth emerged from the last major Ice Age. The investigators showed that mountain glaciers retreated from their maximum position beginning around 21,000 years ago, relatively early compared to other locations, suggesting that a subtle increase in summer sunlight may have had strong effects in the Arctic. A second discovery relates to the pace of glacier retreat during the last period of global warming. The data from this project showed an exceptionally rapid period of glacier recession between 16,000 and 15,000 years ago. The timing and pace of this major episode of glacier retreat suggest that Arctic Alaska behaves differently than elsewhere around the globe, perhaps in response to inter-hemispheric linkages related to changes in ocean circulation. The out-of-synch behavior of the Brooks Range glaciers continued into the current interglacial period when glaciers reached their pre-industrial maximum position as early as about 4500 years ago. This is unusual – most glaciers around the world reached their pre-industrial maximum positions about 500 years ago. The investigators concluded that changing moisture sources, perhaps related to expanding sea-ice over the Arctic Ocean, may influence glacier behavior in Arctic Alaska.

A large collection of core samples of sediments from the bottom of several previously unstudied lakes were taken for this study. The sedimentary sequences contain a large variety of physical and biological properties that were analyzed to infer past climate and environmental changes that occurred following the retreat of glaciers from the region. At one lake, the investigators used the concentration of chlorophyll preserved in the sediment and measured at sub-centimeter scale to reconstruct growing-season temperature extending back about 6000 years with decadal resolution. At another lake, they used the magnetic signature of the sediment to reconstruct aspects of Earth’s geomagnetic field. The sedimentary sequences have been archived at the National Lacustrine Core Facility where they are available to future workers, some with potentially unforeseen scientific questions.

At Northern Arizona University, a postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students and several undergraduate students participated in this research. The students wrote graduate theses focused on different components of the study. Much of the research was presented at conferences and published in journal articles. The graduate students and the principal investigators gave talks to the public about their findings, including one to a native community in northern Alaska. A full-featured documentary film sponsored by Northern Arizona University entitled, “Taking Earth’s Temperature: Delving into Climate’s Past,” was completed in 2014 and aired on many PBS channels across the country. The filmmakers followed the research team to the Brooks Range to document the process of doing fieldwork for this project, and to explain to a general audience why it is important.
